intro: Quercus longinux, commonly known as the longleaf oak, is a species of evergreen oak native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its elongated, narrow leaves that are typically 6–12 inches long and have a leathery texture. The tree produces small, reddish-brown acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Its bark is thick and fissured, providing a rugged appearance. Quercus longinux is often found in dry, sandy soils and is adapted to fire-prone ecosystems.
